Top voted stories

Chinese army kills three Indian soldiers on border

Link: /i/4635964

Three Indian soldiers have died in a skirmish with Chinese soldiers along the border. Beijing claims that the incident occurred after Indian forces crossed the border and fired on Chinese troops. Multiple media reports say the soldiers were not shot but were killed in hand-to-hand combat. Senior military officials of the two sides are meeting to defuse the situation.

6 hours

Man shot as New Mexico protesters try to bring down Spanish conqueror’s statue

Link: /i/4635859

A man was shot on Monday night as protesters in New Mexico’s largest city tried to bring down a bronze statue of a Spanish conquistador outside the Albuquerque Museum, prompting the authorities to announce that the statue would be removed until officials determine the next steps. The man was taken to a hospital and was in critical but stable condition.

7 hours

Apple facing another EU antitrust probe over App Store and Apple services

Link: /i/4636185

Apple is facing another investigation from European Union over anticompetitive complaints over the App Store and Apple Music. This comes as major apps such as Spotify continue to accuse Apple of stifling competition with App Store fees and other iOS features.

4 hours

Trump says he will sign police reform executive order on Tuesday

Link: /i/4634757

4 hours

US retail sales surge record 17.7% in May

Link: /i/4635720

US retail sales jumped back in May as the economy started to reopen. Retail sales jumped by 17.7% in May which was significantly higher than economists expectations of 8.5% increase. The revised retail sales for April reported a decline of 14.7%. However although the rebound witnessed in May, sales were still 6% lower compared to the same month in 2019.

1 hour

China and North Korea ramping up their nuclear weapons arsenals

Link: /i/4633983

Estimates released by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute suggest that China and North Korea are ramping up their nuclear weapon arsenals while other world superpowers are drawing them down. China had 30 more warheads compared to January 2019, while North Korea added up to 20. Meanwhile, the US drew down its arsenal from 6,185 warheads to 5,800.

2 hours

US COVID-19 deaths now projected at over 200,000 by October

Link: /i/4634943

A new forecast by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington projects 201,129 deaths due to COVID-19 in the US through the beginning of October. The IHME raised its estimate by 18% from 169,890. Florida is expected to be among the hardest hit states, with an estimated 18,675 deaths, up 186% from a previous estimate.

1 hour

36 alien races could be communicating in our galaxy, claims study

Link: /i/4632453

As per a new study led by the University of Nottingham, 36 alien civilizations in the Milky Way are actively communicating by broadcasting radio signals into space. The estimate is based on an assumption that intelligent life would evolve on other planets in the same way that it has done on Earth, taking five billion years. The assumption is called the Astrobiological Copernican Limit.

13 hours

Ilhan Omar’s father dies from Covid-19

Link: /i/4636674

Rep. Ilhan Omar’s father died on Monday night of complications from the coronavirus. ’It is with tremendous sadness and pain that I share that my father, Nur Omar Mohamed, passed away due to complications from COVID-19,’ Omar wrote on Twitter. Omar and her father Nur Mohamed came to the US as refugees in 1995 from Somalia during the country’s civil war and eventually settled in Minneapolis.

10 hours

Over 600,000 UK workers lose their jobs during lockdown

Link: /i/4635850

The number of paid UK employees dropped by 2.1% or 612,000 in May compared with March as employers laid off staff and stopped hiring. Universal Credit and Jobseeker’s Allowance claims jumped 23.3% between April and May to 2.8M and have soared 125.9% or 1.6M since March. Overall, the unemployment rate held steady at 3.9% in the 3 months to April.

7 hours

Vietnam couple detained over killing pet dogs and cats for meat

Link: /i/4636181

A couple in Vietnam, accused of poisoning dozens of pet dogs and cats, have been arrested. On Sunday, residents in northern Thanh Hoa province were alerted to bodies of their pets scattered in the streets. Cops later caught the duo ’collecting the dead dogs and cats in bags’. The animals were poisoned with cyanide. The two had rented a house where tools to butcher the animals were found.

5 hours

Man sentenced after shooting himself in groin, blaming it on homeless man

Link: /i/4636179

A Portland man has been sentenced to nearly six years in prison after he accidentally shot himself in the groin but told cops he was robbed and shot at by a homeless man. Marcus Anthony Davis Jr., 35, was on federal supervision for a drug offense at the time of the Jan. 8 shooting. The gun had been reportedly stolen in 2018. Police checked the location and found no evidence of a robbery.

5 hours

HTC’s first 5G smartphone is the mid-range U20

Link: /i/4636056

3 hours

Trump and Seattle Mayor exchange words over autonomous zone

Link: /i/4634733

President Trump on Monday criticized WA Gov. Jay Inslee and Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan for not breaking up a portion of Seattle. He said he would if they don’t but offered no specifics on when or how he might intervene. Durkan replied that Trump ’distracts with lies and language purposefully intended to incite violence. He thrives on division when we desperately need to move forward as a nation.’

11 hours

BOJ leaves monetary policy unchanged, pledges $1 trln to struggling firms

Link: /i/4636057

The BOJ kept its monetary policy unchanged on Tuesday and maintained its view that the economy will gradually recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, signaling that it has taken enough steps to support growth for now. However, it increased the nominal size of its lending packages for cash-strapped firms to $1 trillion from about $700 billion announced in May.

6 hours

France reverses ban on use of chokehold after police protests

Link: /i/4633828

France has decided to revoke the ban on police using the chokehold when arresting suspects after protest from officers that their lives would be put at risk. This comes days after the interior minister, Christophe Castaner, announced that the controversial technique would be dropped after two weeks of French protests following the death of George Floyd in the US.

1 hour

US airlines threaten to ban passengers who refuse to wear masks

Link: /i/4634714

US airline industry’s main lobby group said Monday that passengers who refuse to wear facial coverings could have their flying privileges revoked. Currently, major US airlines may deny anyone not wearing a mask from boarding and/ or provide the masks to passengers who have none. Once on board, however, flight attendants have little power to enforce the wearing of masks.

4 hours

You Can Finally Buy Boston Dynamics’ Spot, But You Can’t Use It For Evil

Link: /i/4637080

23 minutes

Planned Parenthood endorses Joe Biden

Link: /i/4634388

The presumptive Democratic nominee, Joe Biden, was endorsed by Planned Parenthood. The group also praised Biden for his role in the Affordable Care act and his longstanding support for reproductive rights. Some point out Biden’s record on supporting the Hyde amendment, but Pro-Choice Activist are putting hope for Biden as Trump’s appointees could restrict access to abortion and birth control.

United, other major airlines tell passengers to wear face masks or risk getting banned

Link: /i/4635546

1 hour

North Korea ’blows up joint liaison office’ with South

Link: /i/4635905

South Korea says that North Korea has exploded an inter-Korean liaison office building near the border town of Kaesong. The move comes as the North is cutting off regular communications with the South over Seoul’s failure to stop activists from flying propaganda leaflets across the border. Local media reports say smoke could be seen billowing from the structure.

’Star Wars: Squadrons’: Video game with dogfights in a galaxy far, far away

2 hours

NYPD disbands plainclothes anti-crime unit in nod to reform

Link: /i/4634942

The NYPD announced Monday it’s disbanding its anti-crime unit that was involved in the 2014 death of Eric Garner and have long been criticized for aggressive tactics. Commissioner Dermot Shea said 600 plainclothes officers from the unit will be reassigned to other teams. The move came following criticism of the department over the tactics used against protesters during the recent demonstrations.
